doc.field: Addressed To: "Professor E.N. [Eben Norton] Horsford, Cambridge," [MA], "Newark, DE"

Sent From: "James C. Booth of Booth & Garrett (Thomas H.), Laboratory for Practical and Analytical Chemistry, Chant Street, Rear of St. Stephen's Church (Tenth Street, Below Market), Established 1836, Philadelphia," [PA]

In Reference To: Academic / Business / Chemistry / Education / Professional / Science; Copy of Doremus Testimony; [Education & research of Superphosphate used in agriculture]; Mr. Boyle, Professor Friedrich Wöhler, Gottingen, [Gielsen] with Liebig, Berlin [Germany] with Professor Gustav Magnus, Rose & Mitscherlich

James Curtis Booth (July 28, 1810 – March 21, 1888) was an American chemist who was the melter and refiner at the U.S. Mint in Philadelphia for many years. Booth was born in Philadelphia, was educated at the Hartsville Seminary, graduated from the University of Pennsylvania in 1829, and later studied at the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, New York from 1831 to 1832. He visited Germany between 1833 and 1835, spending the year of 1833 in Professor Friedrich Wöhler's private laboratory in Hesse-Cassel, and then spending nine months in the laboratory of Professor Gustav Magnus in Berlin. He opened a chemistry laboratory in Pennsylvania in 1836 for teaching purposes, and when the demand for teaching and chemical analysis increased, he was assisted by Dr. Martin Hans Boyè until 1845. From 1848, Thomas H. Garrett was his associate, and in 1881 the firm became "Booth, Garrett and Blair." The James Curtis Booth Papers (1785-1944) are preserved at the Othmer Library of Chemical History, Chemical Heritage Foundation in Philadelphia, PA.
Booth, James Curtis: Philadelphia, PA: 1844 February 1; 1868 November 1
